Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Methods for High-Resolution Multiscale Analysis in DNA Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental mystery in genome biology is how the three billion base pairs of a mammalian DNA sequence (approximately 2 meters long) are folded, looped, and coiled to fit into a cell nucleus that is roughly 5-10 microns in diameter. Rapid progress has been made over the last few years in advancing our understanding of how the genome folds in three dimensions (3D), primarily driven by advances in sequencing technologies. The goal of this project is to develop mathematical models that will provide a deeper understanding of how 3D genome structure is connected to gene expression in healthy development, and how these folding patterns go awry during the onset and progression of disease.

This project aims to shed new light into the organizing principles governing genome folding through chromatin conformation capture experiments. To date, no clear best practice computational methods exist for the comparison of genome organization across cell types or biological perturbations. The aim of this project is to develop mathematical models and computational methods to gain new insight into how the genetic material folds in different cellular states, and to sensitively detect how these folding patterns are dynamically altered by biological perturbations such as drugs, growth factors, and genome editing. This project focuses on developing methods to sensitively detect dynamic changes in two broad categories of 3D chromatin features: (1) sub-megabase topologically associating domains exhibiting a block structure, and (2) precise long-range interactions between two distant genomic loci, leading to looping out of the intervening genomic DNA. Both parametric and non-parametric normalization approaches for elucidating these features will be explored and benchmarked. Models for these features will be developed, leading to scan statistics for identifying them in normalized 3D contact maps. Methods for false discovery rate control for these scan statistics will be developed based on analysis of heterogeneous Poisson fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Statistical Methods for High-Resolution Multiscale Analysis 3D DNA Interactions.

Intellectual merit: In this proposal, we focus on developing rigorous statistical methods for calling significant 3D interactions in high-resolution 5C data and for quantifying differences in architecture across biological perturbations at the sub-Mb length scale. Fundamentally, we ask the question of what constitutes a biological signal in DNA contacts at the sub-Mb length scale, how to normalize 3C-based data to reveal these signals, and how to represent and test for changes in these signals mathematically. We categorize 3D interactions by two broad categories: (1) sub-Mb level contact domains that have a block structure, and (2) point interactions between two distant loci associated with DNA looping.

Progress: When Dr. Cremins started her lab, the techniques to create high-resolution folding maps were newly published and still under extensive development. There was a great need for computational and experimental tools to find patterns and improve the resolution of the Hi-C assay. Due to Dr. Cremins’s training across disciplines, her team has been actively involved in building tools to increase our understanding of the role for genome folding in cellular state. She published a graph-theory method for quantifying nested subTADs in Hi-C data (Norton+..Phillips-Cremins, Nature Methods, 2018). She published statistical methods for identifying loops in 5C data (Gilgenast+..Phillips-Cremins, Cell Systems, 2019). She has recently devised a statistical method for identifying dynamic loops across lineages (Fernandez+..Phillips-Cremins, Genome Biology, 2020) and applied principles from network science to identify core-periphery structure in TADs (Huang+..Phillips-Cremins, Scientific Reports, 2019). Her lab freely shared all algorithms which have been essential for the discoveries made by others (e.g.  https://bitbucket.org/creminslab/). She and her team have also continued to improve the experimental genome folding techniques (Kim+..Phillips-Cremins, Methods, 2018). Overall, the Cremins lab has made significant progress in developing wet and dry lab tools to facilitate discovery of folding patterns in high-resolution Chromosome-Conformation-Capture data.

In the Cremins lab’s most technologically innovative work on the molecular side,  they have built CRISPR-based light-activated dynamic looping (LADL) tools to engineer the 3D genome in single cells in response to light (Kim+..Phillips-Cremins, Nature Methods, 2019). A critical unknown in the 3D genome field is how dynamic folding is on short time scales of seconds to hours. Although folding patterns are now mapped, their causal control over genome function remains to be elucidated. Inspired by proteins responsible for circadian regulation of flowering in plants, they built synthetic architectural proteins to form long-range contacts with blue light. Given LADL’s ability to engineer loops with rapid kinetics, this raises the open question of the 3D genome’s dynamics on second to minute time scales. Overall, this grant supported all of these manuscripts from concept, to tool development, to publication.

Broader Impacts: This grant has funded research experiences for two undergraduates, two graduate student and two post-baccalaureate students aiming to gain training in working with graph theory statistics and computational principles for analyzing big data. The statistical tools were all made freely available to the growing community of scientists generating and analyzing data from 3C-based technologies. All molecular reagents were made freely available on AddGene. All work was presented by the trainees funded and trained by this grant across all five years at the 4D Nucleome annual meeting.
